Award.AwardTitle: Moving Toward Gravitational Wave Detection in Advanced LIGO
Award.AbstractNarration:
Saulson's research group at Syracuse has been working for two decades to help develop the LIGO gravitational wave detector and to contribute to the search for gravitational waves with the observations that it has made. In the coming three years, the group will develop a new technique to uncover the causes of excess (non-Gaussian) disturbances, or 'glitches',in LIGO's data. They will develop a data-mining system to look for the connection between times subject to disturbances and the values of a wide array of control and monitoring signals. This will allow the exploration of the possibility that saturation of error signals in control systems causes extra sensitivity to environmental disturbances, as well as other mechanisms that can cause time-varying couplings between control channels and the gravitational wave output. Success in this project will allow more confident detections of gravitational wave signals, and will ease the path to future sharing of LIGO data with the public. The Syracuse group will also work to improve Advanced LIGO's search for gravitational waves from the coalescence of a neutron star binary. A specially-focused pipeline will be developed to take full advantage of all of the special features of this signal. This will improve Advanced LIGO's ability to detect signals from this key science target.

When we have succeeded in detecting gravitational waves, we will be able to explore the universe in a completely new way. It will enable us to make unprecedented observations of black holes, and in particular to check whether they behave as predicted by Einstein's General Theory of Relativity. Development of gravitational wave detection techniques has led to advances in U.S. technological capability in lasers, vacuum systems, and precision mechanics, among others. Saulson's group at Syracuse is engaged in formal and informal education at many levels, including undergraduate and graduate training and outreach to the general public. The group also participates in research on the sociology of science, in conjunction with Prof. Harry Collins of Cardiff University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Syracuse group is devoted to the search for gravitational waves and to the study of the universe with this new means of making astronomical observations. We are members of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC), an international group of about 1000 scientists and engineers who carry out the research program of the new Advanced LIGO (aLIGO) interferometers. We also work closely with the Virgo Collaboration in Europe, who have developed a similar instrument and who search for gravitational waves together with the LSC.

   Advanced LIGO is the world's leading instrument for the search for gravitational waves. During the period of this grant, Advanced LIGO was brought into operation and was prepared for its first observing run, to start less than two months after the end of the grant.

   One main priority of our research was improving the methods for searching for signals from binary star systems consisting of two neutron stars, two black holes, or one of each. These so-called "compact binaries" are expected to be both the most numerous signals detected by aLIGO and potentially the most interesting ones as well. When the two black holes in a binary collide with one another, we will be able to observe features of black holes that have been predicted by Einstein's General Theory of Relativity, but that cannot be observed in any other way. When neutron stars collide, we will also learn about the physics of those strange objects, the remains of massive stars that have collapsed down to the size of a small city. We will be able to check whether neutron star collisions are responsible for the enigmatic high-luminosity events called gamma ray bursts. We also hope to learn something about the production of heavy elements in the universe, if they are made in neutron star collisions.

   The Syracuse group worked throughout this grant period on major improvements to the methods that we use to search for gravitational wave signals from compact binaries. We will be able to look for these signals in data from aLIGO with much better sensitivity and reliability than we could have with our previous methods. Since this is a key science target of aLIGO, we have made a very important contribution to its eventual success.

   Our group was also a very active participant in the commissioning process of aLIGO, carrying out studies called "detector characterization". In this work, we examine data from the interferometers to check whether the performance is suitable for actual searches, or whether there are problems that will interfere with detecting gravitational wave signals. If there are problems, we work closely with the scientists doing the interferometer commissioning to suggest possible fixes and to let them know when their fixes have succeeded.  By the end of this grant, we had participated intensively in two engineering runs of aLIGO, and helped prepare the instruments for the upcoming observing run. We were able to diagnose and help solve a number of problems. As the observing run approaches, the interferometers are working well, and the data is of high quality.

   Already, aLIGO is 3 - 4 times more sensitive than its predecessor instrument, Initial LIGO. When all features of aLIGO are fully operational, it will have advanced a factor of 10 in sensitivity beyond Initial LIGO. By the time that has been achieved, we are all but certain to have found some gravitational wave signals, perhaps many of them. We are eagerly looking forward to exploring the universe with gravitational waves in the very near future.
